description: A unanimous decision by the Corry Little League board was made recently to cancel the 2020 season. The decision was made based on recommendations set forth by Little League International and the state as well as discussions with the entities that own local baseball and softball fields- Corry Area School District and the city of Corry.  "It was a very hard and well...
text:
A unanimous decision by the Corry Little League board was made recently to
cancel the 2020 season.

The decision was made based on recommendations set forth by Little League
International and the state as well as discussions with the entities that own
local baseball and softball fields - Corry Area School District and the city
of Corry.

"It was a very hard and well thought out decision by the board to cancel the
2020 Little League season," Corry Little League Vice President John Brundage
said.

As die hard baseball and softball fans, the board felt like it was the right
decision to keep players safe, Brundage said.

A list of recommended guidelines published on the Little League
International's website is very hard to follow with seven pages of
recommendations, he continued.

"Group sizes and social distancing are still going to be required in the green
phase, that alone is not possible to follow when considering players and
families," Brundage said.

Another issue is fields leased for play are owned by the city of Corry and the
school district, who both are following state guidelines.

City Manager Jason Biondi said he's discussed with little league board members
that ballfields are closed to the public with no reopening in sight based on
guidelines and recommendations from the governor.

CASD Business Manager Brenda Clabbatz said when the state closed schools for
the academic year, buildings and properties were closed.

"Until we get further guidance from the state as to the situation with
COVID-19, we won't be reopening anything for this academic year," Clabbatz
said.

Even after Erie County reaches the green phase, the school has to wait for
guidelines and regulations to be released before the fields can be reopened,
Clabbatz said.

Brundage said he doesn't believe the board will reconsider the decision when
the county moves into the green phase.

"Most people don't realize how hard of a decision it was for us. We want
things back to 'normal' just like everyone else," Brundage said.

Parents can expect to see a full refund in the next couple weeks, he said.

"We look forward to being back better than ever for the 2021 season," Brundage
said.

title: Corry Little League cancels 2020 season
html:
A unanimous decision by the Corry Little League board was made recently to cancel the 2020 season.

The decision was made based on recommendations set forth by Little League International and the state as well as discussions with the entities that own local baseball and softball fields - Corry Area School District and the city of Corry.

"It was a very hard and well thought out decision by the board to cancel the 2020 Little League season," Corry Little League Vice President John Brundage said.

As die hard baseball and softball fans, the board felt like it was the right decision to keep players safe, Brundage said.

A list of recommended guidelines published on the Little League International's website is very hard to follow with seven pages of recommendations, he continued.

"Group sizes and social distancing are still going to be required in the green phase, that alone is not possible to follow when considering players and families," Brundage said.

Another issue is fields leased for play are owned by the city of Corry and the school district, who both are following state guidelines.

City Manager Jason Biondi said he's discussed with little league board members that ballfields are closed to the public with no reopening in sight based on guidelines and recommendations from the governor.

CASD Business Manager Brenda Clabbatz said when the state closed schools for the academic year, buildings and properties were closed.

"Until we get further guidance from the state as to the situation with COVID-19, we won't be reopening anything for this academic year," Clabbatz said.

Even after Erie County reaches the green phase, the school has to wait for guidelines and regulations to be released before the fields can be reopened, Clabbatz said.

Brundage said he doesn't believe the board will reconsider the decision when the county moves into the green phase.

"Most people don't realize how hard of a decision it was for us. We want things back to 'normal' just like everyone else," Brundage said.

Parents can expect to see a full refund in the next couple weeks, he said.

"We look forward to being back better than ever for the 2021 season," Brundage said.
